title: 'Childlike' 4ft 4ins woman faces being made homeless after her benefits are axed
text:

The family of a 'childlike' woman with learning disabilities and multiple chronic health problems say she is about to be made homeless as her benefits have been stopped.

Jane Cooper, 55, who is just 4ft 4in tall, has never been able to have a proper job or been in an adult relationship because of her problems.

Despite her learning disabilities and multiple serious physical problems - she has been told she no longer qualifies for Employment and Support Allowance (ESA) which means her housing benefit will stop.

Her married sister Susan Borge told Devon Live that Jane has never had a diagnosis for her condition so 'childlike' is the best way to describe her.

(Image: Devon Live)

She said: "Jane likes to watch things that are funny on the TV, talk to a teddy bear in the car and she still likes children's toys and books.

"Childlike is the perfect way to describe Jane. It's very difficult for me to say this about my sister - but I have worked with people with Down's syndrome and they are more intelligent than she is.

"She was never diagnosed, because years ago they didn't like to label a child as disabled, but you don't need to be a doctor to know that she has problems."

Jane has lived independently in Torquay since both her parents died. She also has chronic health problems and is currently being treated for necrotic toe as a result of progressive diabetes.

(Image: Jeff J Mitchell)

Her neighbours keep an eye on her and her sister acts as her main carer, although she is not paid.

She was on Job Seeker's Allowance (JSA) for 40 years but two years ago - after three spells in hospital - she was switched to ESA which is for people who have a disability or health condition that affects how much they can work.

The family unsuccessfully appealed the decision to cut her benefits and have just been told that the mandatory reconsideration has been turned down by the Department for Work and Pensions.

Now after being turned down for ESA, Jane was told that also means her housing benefit will stop. Susan said: "She will literally lose her home. She is very happy there because everybody looks out for her and they ring me if she needs help.

(Image: UPPA/Photoshot)

"She is feeling very tearful and bamboozled at the moment. I have tried to explain it to her but she gets upset when I talk about it because she doesn't understand.

"I was recently made redundant and have used all my savings to look after her.

"Also I have been taking her to all her appointments and can't get another job because I've been spending all my time trying to sort this out."

The family has written to Matt Hancock, the secretary of state for health and social care, and to Torbay MP Kevin Foster.

Now they are taking the case to an independent tribunal at Newton Abbot magistrates court before Her Majesty’s Courts and Tribunals Service (HMCTS).

A spokesman for the Department of Work and Pensions said it is looking into the case.
description: Jane Cooper, from  Torquay, Devon, who is just 4ft 4in tall, has never been able to have a proper job
